journal-title-group.journal-title: The Journal of Behavioral Health Services & Research

title-group.article-title: Lessons in Implementation from a 5-Year SBIRT Effort Using a Mixed-Methods Approach

contrib-group.aff: 2The Center for Behavioral Health Integration, Montpelier, VT USA

permissions.copyright-statement: © National Council for Mental Wellbeing 2023, Springer Nature or its licensor (e.g. a society or other partner) holds exclusive rights to this article under a publishing agreement with the author(s) or other rightsholder(s); author self-archiving of the accepted manuscript version of this article is solely governed by the terms of such publishing agreement and applicable law.

license.license-p: This article is made available via the PMC Open Access Subset for unrestricted research re-use and secondary analysis in any form or by any means with acknowledgement of the original source. These permissions are granted for the duration of the World Health Organization (WHO) declaration of COVID-19 as a global pandemic.

abstract.p: SBIRT is an effective process to target unhealthy alcohol and other substance use in medical settings, yet gaps persist on how best to integrate SBIRT into routine clinical practice. Utilizing a mixed-methods design, the current study examined a statewide SBIRT implementation effort to identify key components of successful implementation. Quantitative patient-level data (n = 61,121) were analyzed to assess characteristics associated with implementation, and key informant interviews were conducted with stakeholders to understand the implementation process. Findings demonstrated variation in intervention rates, and both site- and patient-level factors influenced SBIRT service delivery. Qualitative results highlighted critical factors shaping these differences, including staff perceptions, type of leadership, degree of flexibility, and the health reform context. Study findings illustrate the importance of a supportive outer context, key facilitators such as buy-in, dynamic leadership, and flexibility during implementation, and the impact of site and patient characteristics for the successful integration of SBIRT into medical settings.

institution-wrap.institution: National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism
Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Unhealthy alcohol consumption and other substance use are serious public health concerns and common problems experienced by patients in medical settings.1–5 Despite numerous policy recommendations calling for attention to alcohol and other substance use, they are generally under-recognized and undertreated in the medical system.6–11 The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends annual alcohol screening and brief behavioral counseling for adults, as well as screening for unhealthy drug use.12–15 Alcohol screening and brief counseling ranks fourth on a list of the top 28 effective clinical preventive services for the US population.16 Moreover, there is a call to both outpatient and emergency department providers to do a better job identifying and intervening with opioid, stimulant, and other substance use problems,17–22 particularly in light of increasing overdose rates and deaths since the COVID-19 pandemic hit in March 2020.23–26 The need for effective strategies to address substance misuse is even more pronounced in rural communities where there are generally fewer services available to serve individuals spread across wider geographical terrain, often making prevention and treatment resources harder to access and deliver.27–30

States, payers, hospitals, health care systems, and provider groups need effective tools to address alcohol and other substance use at a population level. One promising approach is Screening, Brief Intervention, and Referral to Treatment (SBIRT), an evidence-based process for identifying and addressing alcohol and other substance use risk. In the SBIRT process, validated screening tools are utilized universally to identify patients’ risk levels which in turn are matched with appropriate interventions. Patients that screen low to moderate are suitable for a brief intervention (BI), which is often conducted at the time of screening, while those that screen high, or severe, will need a referral to treatment (RT) and necessitate further assessment and diagnosis. While not included in the SBIRT acronym, brief treatment (BT) is another level of intervention often bundled with SBIRT, which is appropriate for patients that screen at moderate risk. Importantly, the SBIRT process is not a single health care intervention; rather, SBIRT comprises a series of interconnected and interrelated clinical strategies, often making implementation more complex and requiring longer implementation timeframes.31,32

SBIRT implementation efforts are taking shape around the country through Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA)-funded grants, state programs, private foundation support, and other funding and technical assistance mechanisms. The SBIRT framework is also recognized as a strategy for rural communities to target substance misuse.33 Despite a growing body of research demonstrating SBIRT’s efficacy in addressing alcohol and other substance use in medical settings, the use of the SBIRT process is still not widespread, often due to implementation challenges.34,35 Gaps persist in the implementation science on how best to integrate SBIRT into routine clinical practice,36–38 particularly how SBIRT effectiveness may differ by medical setting, patient use and risk patterns, and workflow characteristics.

To date, SBIRT implementation literature has primarily focused on identifying barriers and facilitators to screening and brief intervention (SBI), the initial components of the SBIRT process. 34,37–44 Significantly fewer studies exist that examine implementation of the full SBIRT process, including the referral component, which is critical as a recent study demonstrated that greater intervention intensity is associated with better outcomes.45 More recently, research examining implementation of the full SBIRT process identified the importance of buy-in,46 as well as leadership and alignment of SBIRT with other organizational priorities,47 as essential facilitators. Notable implementation barriers in these studies included time constraints and medical professionals’ discomfort in discussing the topic of substance use.46,47

One study examining results from the first seven states that received funding from SAMHSA to implement SBIRT reported six key themes critical for comprehensive SBIRT implementation.35 These include committed leadership, intra- and inter-organizational communication and collaboration, provider buy-in and acceptance, contextual factors (e.g., physical space, technology, patient characteristics), quality assurance, and grant requirements. According to the authors, elements can be viewed as facilitators or barriers depending on their presence or absence during implementation.35 While this early research examining implementation of the full SBIRT process identifies important organizational and systemic barriers and facilitators, additional studies are needed that replicate and extend these findings. Further, few studies have focused on the role of state and local health system transformation efforts on SBIRT implementation and SBIRT implementation characteristics in rural settings.

Gaps also exist in which implementation characteristics are most important, and under what conditions. To date, most SBIRT implementation studies have separately discussed implementation facilitators and barriers, the impact of patient and site characteristics 48 on implementation, or care delivery outcomes related to implementation,49–51 making it difficult to translate SBIRT implementation findings into real-world lessons.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: The present study focuses on a statewide SBIRT implementation initiative in Vermont. Over the past decade, Vermont (a predominantly rural state) has engaged in a series of health care delivery system and payment reform innovations to improve health care.52 The Vermont Blueprint for Health—a state-led, nationally recognized initiative that supports community-led strategies to improve health—is focused on investing in primary care through the Patient-Centered Medical Home (PCMH) model,53 as well as enhancing medications for opioid use disorder (MOUD) through Vermont’s Hub and Spoke program.54 Before SBIRT implementation in Vermont, significant inroads had been made to address behavioral health within primary care but did not include substance use. SBIRT implementation in Vermont extends these other health reform efforts.

In 2013, the Vermont Department of Health received a 5-year SAMHSA grant to support SBIRT implementation with the goal of screening 15% of the state’s adult population. Participating sites were selected based on organization type, size, and readiness, and included federally qualified health centers, free clinics, regional medical center emergency departments, and university health services. All but two of the participating sites were in rural communities. Sites began SBIRT implementation on a staggered basis between 2014 and 2016.

Participating sites were provided with orientation training and planning modules for leadership, administrative, and clinical staff. The project team, led by two of the authors, met with SBIRT champions and other staff to identify how key elements would fit within their workflow. For example, in some of the emergency department sites, initial screening questions were administered during triage. Then, due to the wait time patients might have while receiving care, SBIRT clinicians (interventionists) were tasked with interviewing patients with the secondary screening questions and moving right into a BI depending on the results. Separately, at a university health services outpatient site, patients completed both the initial and secondary screening questions via a check-in kiosk and tablet. The results were then accessed by the provider electronically and the SBIRT intervention was integrated into the medical visit.

During the first months of implementation at a new site, project staff were on-site to support technical assistance and coaching as SBIRT services were delivered. Other training modules helped staff in planning for workflow, evaluation, and health IT infrastructure needs. On-going training and technical assistance opportunities included continuous quality assurance, clinical supervision, and on-site coaching to ensure fidelity and competence to the SBIRT process.

The current study aims to extend the SBIRT literature by increasing knowledge of how the full SBIRT process is implemented in medical settings, including how implementation barriers and facilitators from the SBIRT literature35 manifest during implementation and influence the outcomes of implementation. Two additional unique elements of the current study include the statewide health reform context and the rural nature of Vermont within which SBIRT was implemented. This paper describes both quantitative and qualitative findings, connects these findings with the larger SBIRT implementation context, and shares lessons learned.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: This study employed a sequential explanatory mixed-methods design55 to analyze the SBIRT implementation process and service delivery outcomes in Vermont medical settings. The quantitative phase examined SBIRT service delivery rates, by site and across sites, post-implementation, and predicted factors associated with SBIRT intervention. Quantitative results of SBIRT service delivery rates helped inform site selection for the second component of the study—a comparative case study of SBIRT implementation in four medical organizations. This study was determined exempt from the Brandeis University Institutional Review Board.

sec.title: Quantitative methods
sec.p: Deidentified quantitative data from the SBIRT Vermont dataset and the GPRA (Center for Substance Abuse Treatment’s Government Performance Results and Modernization Act Client Outcomes Measures) data collection instrument56 were merged to construct the dataset for the study. To evaluate alcohol and other substance use risk, the dataset included the Alcohol Use Disorders Identification Test (AUDIT-10)57,58 and the Drug Abuse Screening Test (DAST-10)59 total scores, which can be stratified into the following four risk levels: none, low, moderate, or severe. The level of intervention received was coded as the highest, or most intensive, level of intervention provided, which ranged from screening only, brief intervention (BI), brief treatment (BT), or a referral to substance use disorder (SUD) treatment (RT). To evaluate whether the level of intervention a patient received matched the level of risk (based on AUDIT and/or DAST screening scores), an “intervention match” variable was created. This variable was coded as a “match” when a patient received at least the level of intervention indicated based on screening risk level (i.e., low = at least BI, moderate = at least BT, severe = RT).

The final dataset included patient-level data (Table 1) of screened patients from 10 SBIRT Vermont implementing organizations (n = 61,121). Patient-level characteristics (Table 1) included demographics, alcohol and other substance use risk level, and other risk and protective behavior screening results (e.g., tobacco use, texting while driving, seatbelt/helmet use, whether patient received flu shot). Additional risk and protective behaviors were introduced at the beginning of the universal screen to normalize the alcohol and substance use screen as an additional area of wellness with the hope of reducing stigma and increasing honest responses. Site characteristics (e.g., implementation time, site size, SBIRT administrative method) for each of the 10 sites were also added to the dataset (Table 2).Table 1

Data collection began in February 2014 and continued through July 31, 2018 (grant end). Data analyzed for this study include data submitted between February 2014 and May 30, 2017. All sites were designated in the dataset as being part of implementation wave 1 (SBIRT service delivery initiated between February 2014 and August 2014) or wave 2 (SBIRT service delivery initiated between December 2015 and December 2016) to study the implementation time period but not identify specific organizations. Six organizations began SBIRT service delivery during wave 1 and four sites started during the second wave.

The analysis approach for the quantitative phase of the study first involved calculating SBIRT service delivery rates between and across sites, which was followed by multivariate logistic regression modeling to assess the impact of site- and patient-level factors on (1) the likelihood of a patient receiving SBIRT (“any intervention”) and (2) the likelihood of a patient that screened positive receiving the appropriate level of SBIRT intervention based on alcohol and/or substance use risk (“intervention match”). To ensure a parsimonious model fit, each of the site- and patient-level predictor variables were investigated for interactions and collinearity in the model. 60 A standard (limited variables of interest) and expanded model (included additional risk and protective behavior variables—i.e., tobacco use, seatbelt use, and flu shot receipt)1 were run for each of the analyses to better understand associated factors. All analyses were conducted using Stata, version 15. The quantitative results helped define how patient characteristics may influence SBIRT implementation and informed site selection for the comparative case study, which drilled into the implementation process of four of the implementing organizations.

sec.title: Case study methods
sec.p: For the comparative case study, a purposeful site selection process61,62 was used to designate four cases from the 10 sites studied in the quantitative phase. The four cases were selected from specific criteria to compare, contrast, and identify similarities and differences.63Case selection criteria included a range of site-level characteristics to ensure that each case selected could be compared and contrasted on similar elements. One important criterion involved selecting medium to large sites (i.e., with enough patient volume). Other criteria included the length of time since SBIRT implementation, screening volume and SBIRT service delivery rates (from quantitative results), the statewide SBIRT project team’s perspective, and site willingness to participate in the study. To examine the process of implementation, Greenhalgh and colleagues’ Conceptual Model for Considering the Determinants of Diffusion, Dissemination, and Implementation of Innovations in Health Service Delivery and Organization64 was used throughout the case study design and analysis. The SBIRT Program Matrix ,31 a conceptual framework for SBIRT program implementation and evaluation, helped to evaluate and contextualize SBIRT implementation characteristics and outcomes.

Case study data collection involved site visits, semi-structured key informant interviews (n = 17), and a review of select administrative documents for each of the four sites (e.g., SBIRT policies and procedures, SBIRT implementation planning documents, SBIRT patient education materials). Key informants included individuals from each site (e.g., physician champions, SBIRT clinicians, nurses, administrators) who were involved with SBIRT provision of care and/or implementation efforts and could discuss the organization’s implementation process. Site and informant participation was voluntary, and three to six informants participated from each site. Most interviews were scheduled with participants during the site visit, but in some instances, telephone interviews were conducted. Key informant interviews were 60 min in duration and were recorded and transcribed for analysis. The interview guide was informed by the study’s conceptual framework and the SBIRT literature and covered a range of topics pertaining to organizational readiness, implementation process, SBIRT service provision (e.g., screening process), implementation facilitators and barriers, program changes and modifications, and planning for sustainability.

In line with the conceptual framework, additional sources of background data were included to help contextualize SBIRT implementation. This included background conversations with members of the statewide SBIRT project team to understand the SBIRT implementation support that was offered to sites during the SAMHSA grant (e.g., type of training and technical assistance, implementation tools and resources available, monitoring, quality assurance). Background conversations also took place with Vermont government, behavioral health, and health reform leaders to contextualize the statewide policy and health reform environment and outer system characteristics at play in Vermont during SBIRT implementation.

For analysis, deductive and inductive analytical methods were used through content analysis and case comparisons to identify themes and findings present within and across case study sites. The deductive analysis used an initial coding scheme—based on the conceptual framework, interview guide, and SBIRT implementation literature—to analyze each case in-depth and compare a priori domains across cases. As new patterns emerged in the data through inductive analysis, the coding scheme was updated. The unit of analysis was at the site level. ATLAS.ti 8 analytic software was used to organize case study data and facilitate coding and analysis.

sec.title: Quantitative
sec.p:
Across the 10 SBIRT implementation sites, 15% (n = 9157) of screened patients were positive for unhealthy alcohol and/or other substance use, and nearly 11% (n = 6500) received some level of SBIRT intervention (i.e., BI, BT, RT). The level of intervention received, however, was not always the appropriate intervention match as indicated by the AUDIT-10 and/or DAST-10 screening score(s). Wide variation was present in BI, BT, RT, and overall intervention delivery rates across the implementation sites (see Table 3).Table 3
SBIRT intervention rates, by site

The screen positive rate is the number of patients at low, moderate, or severe risk (determined by AUDIT-10 or DAST-10 score) divided by the total number of patients screened. Indicated refers to the intervention level (e.g., BI, BT, RT) determined by patient risk score (i.e., AUDIT-10, DAST-10). Delivery rate is the number of patients receiving at least the level of intervention indicated divided by the total number indicated. The overall intervention rate is the site’s delivery rate across all levels of intervention. The total overall intervention rate is the average rate across all sites

Tables 4 and 5 present the logistic regression results analyzing factors associated with SBIRT intervention delivery. Both site- and patient-level factors influenced SBIRT service provision in the analysis. Based on expanded logistic regression analyses, emergency department settings (OR: 7.95, 95%, CI: 2.83, 22.37) and sites with bachelor’s degree levels (OR: 3.70, 95%, CI: 1.26, 10.85) and mixed provider types (e.g., master’s-level, physician, nurse versus licensed master’s-level professional only) used in SBIRT delivery (OR: 5.30, 95%, CI: 2.17, 12.93) were significantly more likely to receive an SBIRT intervention. Sites in the second implementation wave (OR: 0.19, 95%, CI: 0.08, 0.47), however, were significantly less likely to deliver an SBIRT intervention overall compared to sites in wave 1.Table 4

The results also highlighted the role of patient demographics and screening scores. Low, moderate, and severe risk scores on the AUDIT-10 and DAST-10 were significant predictors of whether a patient received an SBIRT intervention. On the other hand, older age groups (55 and older), being female (OR: 0.83, 95%, CI: 0.75, 0.91), and patients who engaged in select protective factors (e.g., wearing a seatbelt, getting a flu shot) were significantly less likely to receive an SBIRT intervention.

Results for the expanded model examining intervention match among patients that screened positive shared some similarities, as well as marked differences, from the “any intervention” models. Like the “any intervention” model results, emergency department sites (OR: 9.70, 95%, CI: 3.46, 27.20) and sites utilizing mixed provider types in their SBIRT workflows (OR: 3.86, 95%, CI: 1.62, 9.19) were positive predictors of delivering matched interventions. Only low-risk AUDIT-10 (OR: 1.91, 95%, CI: 0.07, 0.10) and DAST-10 (OR: 1.25, 95%, CI: 1.04, 1.49) scores made a patient more likely to receive an intervention match. AUDIT-10 and DAST-10 score ranges in the moderate and severe risk categories were significant negative predictors of intervention match. Patient demographic and protective factors in this model also showed mixed results (see Table 5).

sec.title: Case study findings
sec.p:
The comparative case study evaluated SBIRT implementation in four sites. Three of the four sites were emergency departments in rural regional medical centers and the fourth represented a university health services clinic. Table 6 depicts the SBIRT workflow that each site utilized during implementation.Table 6
Case study SBIRT model and workflow characteristics
ScreeningBIBTRT
Case ATriage nurse (primary screen); SBIRT clinician (secondary screen)SBIRT clinicianSBIRT clinicianSBIRT clinician
Case BSBIRT clinicianSBIRT clinicianSBIRT clinicianSBIRT clinician
Case CSBIRT clinicianSBIRT clinicianSBIRT clinicianSBIRT clinician
Case DCheck-in kiosk (primary screen); tablet (secondary screen)Medical provider or warm handoff to SBIRT clinicianMedical provider makes referral or warm handoff to SBIRT clinicianMedical provider makes referral or warm handoff to SBIRT clinician

Case study sites experienced a range of barriers and facilitators throughout implementation, which according to informants, either supported or impeded the development and maturity of their SBIRT programs. Four main themes were present in the implementation strategy across all four sites, and in the outcomes. First, SBIRT was perceived as being integral to promoting patient wellness. Informants reported that SBIRT was regarded across the setting as a “beneficial” clinical process to target alcohol and other substance use. A physician champion in an emergency department setting noted that before SBIRT there were very few tools for addressing alcohol and other substance use in their hospital, and that SBIRT is “…definitely filling a gap” left by traditional medicine. Another physician champion commented:
This gave us a tool to screen for what we know is often high-risk behavior and it was structured. Then we had a way to act on it. So, it fit with the medical model of efficiency, “Hey, we can have them [patients] do this thing [screening]. We can interpret the results. We can engage with them about risk.” … [SBIRT] was there; it was a structured, automatic way to make it be part of our care.

Other informants discussed the benefits of SBIRT as a preventive intervention. A physician champion stated, “What I love about SBIRT … It’s a preventative application, which I’m a big believer in preventative medicine and education. SBIRT, really, is most effective for that population. It just does education.”

Informants also discussed how the “fatigue” experienced by providers and other clinical staff—particularly those in emergency department settings who were repeatedly treating patients with more severe use patterns—influenced SBIRT buy-in and model acceptance. One SBIRT clinician reported:
I get it. People [patients] who are brought in here with substance use issues are often not at their best and not very friendly to the providers. So, they [e.g., providers] had seen the worst of the worst behavior and the same folks over and over again, and really didn’t understand. …When we started this [SBIRT implementation], the nurses and the providers saw it as the Referral to Treatment piece, not the early intervention and prevention piece.

According to informants, a critical aspect of promoting buy-in among providers and other clinical staff was fostering an understanding of SBIRT as an overall model to support patient wellness—focused on prevention and early identification, as well as one that cares for patients with SUDs.

SBIRT was also viewed by informants as a critical facilitator to support behavioral health integration and reduce stigma around SUDs in health care settings. While the problem of stigma did not fully disappear after SBIRT implementation, a SBIRT clinician remarked that the SBIRT process “helped de-stigmatize patients,” particularly patients with moderate and severe use patterns. Key informants noted that the perceptions surrounding the benefits of SBIRT directly impacted the initial adoption decision, assimilation of SBIRT into their organization, and the continued implementation process.

Another theme was the importance of committed leadership efforts, including a strong and knowledgeable champion to spearhead the implementation process. Across each of the cases, this designated leader was a physician champion, often the medical director. In discussing the influence of leadership, a nursing leader reported that effective implementation for their site was a medical champion “that is in charge … to be really proactive in the sense of saying, ‘Come on. We can do this. Remember this [SBIRT] is beneficial’.” Another informant, an SBIRT clinician, commented that effective leadership is “saying this is something that we’re going to do and making sure that they [the staff] had an opportunity to do it.” Consistently noted as the “key ingredient” of successful SBIRT implementation, informants discussed how leadership not only charted the implementation path, but also served as foundational support for other necessary facilitators like communication, buy-in to the SBIRT model, and contextual factors (e.g., physical space, technology innovations). A physician champion stated, “I think you just have to have strong leadership. …We just kept it up as a consistent drumbeat, an expectation, we’re not going back … We’re doing this, and feeding in plain speech, plain language, why it’s important. And involving everybody.” Key informants also discussed how leadership was critical for moving their SBIRT process into routine practice and preparing to sustain the work after grant funding concluded.

A third cross-cutting theme included the need for organizations to implement SBIRT flexibly in diverse ways. Informants reported that SBIRT model and workflow decisions were made, in part, to conform to organizational structure, preexisting workflow arrangements, available staffing and provider types, and patient characteristics in their clinical setting and the local community. Informants across the case study sites discussed how SBIRT model decisions directly impacted how they implemented SBIRT and, over time, which components of the SBIRT process they had more success with and/or ended up prioritizing. For instance, sites using multiple team members and/or electronic screening versus only the SBIRT clinician reported more success with universal screening due to having greater staff availability to conduct screening (e.g., nursing support) or through an electronic check-in kiosk. On the other hand, sites relying solely on SBIRT clinicians to deliver all elements of the SBIRT process expressed that they had more staffing time for BT and referral linkages, leading to greater reported success in engaging patients with more severe use patterns. Informants also noted the challenges and consequences that came from workflow decisions, priority areas, and how they structured their SBIRT programs. One physician champion stated:
If you’re going to do less time with screening and maybe even brief intervention and try to spend more time getting them [patients] into treatment and following up with them [patients], you’re going to lose a little bit of what the grant is looking for [public health approach], but I think everybody would agree … is that you’re really doing what’s good for the community and for the patient.

Another physician champion said, “The downside is if we spend more time on that end [with higher risk patients], how much are we missing on trying to identify as many patients as we can who might be at risk, and then preventing them to get to that part? I think that is probably a barrier for us.” This often led to a balancing act, according to informants, in how to best meet the needs of the patient population and stay true to the philosophy of SBIRT. An SBIRT clinician commented, “That’s the challenge. Balancing that. They love for us to do as many, be out there, screen, screen, screen but we can’t. In order to be effective at getting people into treatment and doing what’s made us so effective is building the relationships on the outside and so it’s a constant balance …” Another SBIRT clinician discussed how the purpose of SBIRT is “not to just find folks that are at that high-risk category, but also Mr. Jones who broke his leg … and it turns out he had four wines before walking down a steep driveway. Having that conversation … is also important.”

Finally, a fourth theme involved the importance of context and timing with other delivery system reform efforts occurring in Vermont. Vermont’s SBIRT implementation began soon after the passage of the 2010 Affordable Care Act (ACA)65 during a time of considerable state-led delivery system and payment transformation. Informants discussed that “this spirit” of health reform and system change fostered SBIRT implementation in their organizations, but they also noted that coordination and integration between these outer contextual factors and SBIRT did not consistently take place. Some informants discussed how the better alignment of delivery system changes (e.g., Hub and Spoke with SBIRT) would have further supported and improved SBIRT implementation success at their sites.

Additionally, informants from sites in rural areas discussed the “environmental or community barriers of being in a very small town,” and how rural characteristics, treatment system barriers, and other outer contextual factors influenced SBIRT implementation. Despite regional treatment networks and multiple system-wide improvements taking place within the SUD treatment system in Vermont (e.g., Hub and Spoke model), a lack of treatment slots was noted as a significant implementation barrier by informants. Moreover, with the rural nature of Vermont, SBIRT clinicians reported that geographical distance was another barrier to referrals and care linkages.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Results from the current study replicate and extend the SBIRT implementation literature by examining implementation factors for the full SBIRT process in relation to service delivery outcomes within a rural state context. In the current study, acceptance and buy-in of SBIRT involved a philosophical belief in SBIRT as not only an effective tool for addressing alcohol and other substance use but more importantly, as integral to promoting patient wellness. SBIRT buy-in and acceptance among providers and other clinical team members in this study were fostered by strong, committed leadership steering the implementation process. This finding mirrors other studies from the field demonstrating the importance of both buy-in and leadership for successful SBIRT implementation.35,46,66 Without leaders championing SBIRT throughout implementation, it is more difficult to implement and fully integrate the SBIRT process into routine practice.

Flexibility was another vital component of successful SBIRT implementation in this study. As SBIRT is an interrelated and integrated process that includes more than one intervention and often involves multiple team members, departments, or even partnering with other organizations, greater flexibility and adaptability may be needed during implementation as has been noted in the literature.31,35 The present study results highlight the importance of workflow flexibility and adaptability during SBIRT implementation as evidenced in part by greater success with intervention delivery among sites with a range of SBIRT provider qualifications and among sites with self-reported lower rates of universal screening in an effort to prioritize treatment referrals. Such flexibility is critical for implementation within rural regional medical centers as evidenced in part by varying workflows across sites. Implementation decisions like these that prioritize one part of the process over another, however, may force organizations to make tradeoffs, sacrifice fidelity or quality, and/or deal with other unintended consequences. While greater flexibility and adaptability appear to be crucial factors for successful SBIRT implementation, these results also show the need for organizations to assess the strengths and limitations of implementation decisions along the way.

A notable element in the implementation science literature is the importance of the external environment, or outer context/setting, in the implementation process.64,67 The current study advances the SBIRT implementation literature by showing how implementation efforts have a greater chance for success when they align with—and occur within—larger statewide or system-wide transformation, and with flexibility. The dynamics at play in the national and state post-ACA policy environment influenced Vermont’s statewide adoption of SBIRT, including how sites implemented the process within a largely rural state. The state and local context, or “spirit” of health reform and change, was present in the Vermont SBIRT implementation process and according to informants, helped spearhead SBIRT implementation in medical settings.

In viewing the quantitative results, a key finding was variability present in SBIRT service delivery outcomes across sites despite all sites receiving grant funding, training, and technical assistance. It is possible that grant requirements, or other implementation barriers (e.g., limited buy-in, lack of leadership, patient characteristics, rural versus urban considerations), created greater obstacles for some organizations over others. Variable service delivery outcomes have also been present in other research suggesting the importance of considering multi-level (e.g., site, patient, environment) factors during SBIRT implementation.48

Both site- and patient-level characteristics were associated with SBIRT service delivery outcomes in the present study. Regarding site characteristics, emergency departments within rural communities appeared to have had more success with SBIRT intervention delivery compared to outpatient primary care sites. The nature of emergency department visits often includes more time (e.g., waiting for a test or procedure) for SBIRT service provision than in primary care, which may have played a role in the study findings.

Study results suggest that an awareness of differences based on patient characteristics may help sites improve their overall intervention delivery.39,48 While the quantitative results in this study were somewhat mixed, patient demographics (e.g., gender, age), alcohol and other substance use risk, and select protective factors (e.g., seatbelt use, receiving a flu shot) influenced SBIRT service delivery outcomes, suggesting that while patient characteristics likely play a role in SBIRT service provision, the full relationship was not explained in this analysis. More work is needed to better understand how these factors play out during SBIRT implementation. For instance, the quantitative findings illuminated how lower risk patients were more likely to receive the appropriate level of SBIRT intervention than those in higher risk categories. This finding may indicate treatment reticence among higher risk patients in the study—where they were perhaps willing to engage in a BI, but declined BT or a treatment referral. Identifying as female, older, and endorsing certain protective behaviors (e.g., wearing a seatbelt, obtaining the flu shot) was related to a decreased likelihood of receiving an SBIRT intervention. Ideally, SBIRT should be implemented within medical settings uniformly, however, these findings speak to a need to understand how implicit biases, cultural messages, and stigma may negatively impact SBIRT implementation.

Finally, limitations present in this study are important to mention. The study relied heavily on the natural environment during a grant-funded, Vermont-based, SBIRT implementation effort. Thus, it was not possible to control for potentially confounding changes in the external or internal contexts of the state and/or specific sites. While the mixed-methods design did offer an opportunity to mitigate some of the potential confounds, generalizability is limited. Further, the patient sample in this study lacked racial and ethnic diversity (i.e., 95% White), which may limit the generalizability of quantitative findings to other populations, communities, and states. Another notable limitation was patient census data were not available for all sites, which impacted the ability of the study to evaluate screening rates as an outcome. Regarding the qualitative case study, the case selection criteria may have resulted in more “successful” sites being selected for inclusion. The natural exclusion, or omission, of less successful sites, may have limited the current study’s ability to comprehensively provide greater information on barriers to implementation. Further, site visits and key informant interviews were conducted at one point in time after SBIRT implementation, and as such, there was potential recall bias among key informants. The interview guide was designed and structured in a manner to minimize this problem.

sec.title: Implications for Behavioral Health
sec.p: SBIRT is a beneficial process for addressing unhealthy alcohol and other substance use in medical settings but often falls short of being successfully implemented due to barriers and implementation challenges. The results of this study echo other implementation findings from the field, expanding those findings by adding important lessons, within a rural state context, for stakeholders engaged in SBIRT implementation and broader behavioral health care integration efforts. Study findings demonstrate that SBIRT can be most successfully implemented when the following factors are present: a favorable health reform outer context supportive of behavioral health integration; key implementation facilitators such as buy-in, strong leadership (e.g., champions), and communication; flexibility of model and workflow decisions; and a positive perception of the SBIRT process among medical team members. Fostering and encouraging supportive implementation factors like these throughout the implementation process will help organizations plan for, implement, and ultimately move SBIRT into routine practice.

In addition, an awareness of how specific site (e.g., setting type, size, providers) and/or patient characteristics (e.g., demographics, risk level, protective factors) may positively or negatively influence the implementation process may also promote better integration of SBIRT into care settings. The first is the critical importance of recognizing how differences in medical settings directly influence SBIRT implementation. The mixed-methods results of this study suggest, as have other findings in the literature,39,48 that adapting to site-level differences, may increase SBIRT implementation success. Finally, continued research is needed to increase engagement of more intensive interventions (e.g., BT, referral) among patients with moderate to severe risk and to understand the impact of biases and stigma on the implementation process.

fn.p: Patient-level variables with greater than 10% missing were not included in the logistic regression models.
